abstract.text: Update your apps to use new features, and test your apps against API changes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Foundation in macOS 10.14, iOS 12, watchOS 5, and tvOS 12 includes new features, API changes, and deprecations. For information about earlier releases, see

classes have new initializers and helper methods that make it easier for you to enable secure coding for archival and unarchival. Each initializer or helper method replaces a corresponding member that’s now deprecated.

method when unarchiving instances that are subclasses of one of the list of classes you supply. You can use these initializers and helper methods in apps that are compatible with macOS 10.13, iOS 11, watchOS 4, tvOS 11, and subsequent releases of each operating system.
For more information, see the WWDC 2018 session
to archive and unarchive data by enabling
list to decode objects by calling the new
method. By default, this list includes all property list types—
To transform top-level values of types other than the defaults listed above, subclass
If you expect to decode a top-level value of only one allowed type, override
to return that type. Doing so populates
If you expect to decode a top-level value of one of several allowed types, override
classes now support limited conformance to the
You can securely encode pointer-function consuming collections as long as you configure them with the following personalities and kinds of memory:
Weak values won’t round-trip as expected unless you strongly reference them elsewhere during unarchival.

is a new macro for declaring enumerations. You use it only for enumerations that are guaranteed to never gain an additional case. Usually you determine that there won’t be new cases because the enumeration you’re modeling represents a mathematically complete set.
macro. It won’t ever gain additional cases.

Once an enumeration is marked as closed, it’s a binary- and source-incompatible change to add a new value. If you have any doubt about an enumeration gaining a private or additional public case in the future, use the
and choosing between it and other macros for grouping constants, see
has several bug fixes and improvements:
Removed synchronization requirements. It’s no longer necessary to use
. These methods will be deprecated in a future version of the OS.Now that you don’t need to call these synchronization methods, the performance characteristics of
and Preferences Utilities are slightly different: The time taken for enqueueing write operations is now paid by the writing thread, rather than by the next thread to call
Removed retains when adding an observer. Adding observers to an instance of
method unintentionally retained it, unlike all other uses of key-value observing. This has been corrected, and normal Cocoa memory management rules are now followed.

. Reading defaults on one thread while another thread set defaults could nondeterministically send key-value observing notifications on both threads, rather than just the thread doing the set operation. This is now fixed.
no longer throws exceptions when encountering certain kinds of internal errors. Instead, it returns an error in the error argument of the completion handler of the
method. The error might include the
If your app encounters an error when using
, request the resource again or display a prompt to your user to try again.

includes new thread-safety improvements. Accessing the property blocks if other threads are in the process of loading the bundle. This action allows the property to return the correct value in all cases.
function doesn’t do anything in apps linked on or after macOS 10.14, iOS 12, watchOS 5, and tvOS 12. This API will be deprecated in a future release.
In apps linked on earlier versions of macOS, iOS, watchOS, and tvOS, the
function doesn’t do anything if the message port already has a dispatch queue associated with itself via the
function. Previously, this pattern would result in undefined behavior.
In all cases, if you need to change the name of a

abstract.text: Add macros to your Objective-C types to group their values in Swift.
For the specified domain, writes all pending changes to preference data to permanent storage, and reads latest preference data from permanent storage.
Writes to permanent storage all pending changes to the preference data for the application, and reads the latest preference data from permanent storage.
Schedules callbacks for the specified message port on the specified dispatch queue.
Returns a CFMessagePort object connected to a remote port.
Sets the name of a local CFMessagePort object.
Returns a local CFMessagePort object.
A reference to a message port object.
A representation of the code and resources stored in a bundle directory on disk.
The bundle’s principal class.
Constants that indicate sort order.
An object representing a static ordered collection, for use instead of an  constant in cases that require reference semantics.
A resource manager you use to download content hosted on the App Store at the time your app needs it.
Requests access to the resources marked with the managed tags. If any of the resources are not on the device, they are requested from the App Store.
A static byte buffer that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
A representation of a specific point in time, for use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An object representing a static collection of key-value pairs, for use instead of a  constant in cases that require reference semantics.
Could not read, for unknown reasons.
A collection similar to a set, but with broader range of available memory semantics.
An encoder that stores an object’s data to an archive referenced by keys.
Initializes an archiver to encode data into a given a mutable-data object.
Archives an object graph rooted at a given object to a file at a given path.
Returns a data object that contains the encoded form of the object graph formed by the given root object.
Encodes an object graph with the given root object into a data representation, optionally requiring secure coding.
Creates an archiver to encode data, and optionally disables secure coding.
A decoder that restores data from an archive referenced by keys.
Indicates whether the receiver requires all unarchived classes to conform to .
Initializes an archiver to decode data from the specified location.
Decodes and returns the object graph previously encoded by `NSKeyedArchiver` and stored in a given `NSData` object.
Decodes and returns the object graph previously encoded by `NSKeyedArchiver` written to the file at a given path.
Decodes a previously-archived object graph, and returns the root object.
Initializes an archiver to decode data.
Initializes an archiver to decode data from the specified location.
Decodes a previously-archived object graph, returning the root object as one of the specified classes.
Decodes a previously-archived object graph, and returns the root object as the specified type.
A collection similar to a dictionary, but with a broader range of available memory semantics.
A singleton object used to represent null values in collection objects that don’t allow `nil` values.
An object wrapper for primitive scalar numeric values.
An instance of `NSPointerFunctions` defines callout functions appropriate for managing a pointer reference held somewhere else.
Use strong write-barriers to backing store; use garbage-collected memory on copy-in.
Use shifted pointer for the hash value and direct comparison to determine equality; use the `description` method for a description.
Use `hash` and `isEqual` methods for hashing and equality comparisons, use the `description` method for a description.
Use the memory acquire function to allocate and copy items on input (see ).
Uses weak read and write barriers appropriate for ARC or GC. Using NSPointerFunctionsWeakMemory object references will turn to `NULL` on last release.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A value transformer that converts data to and from classes that support secure coding.
A list of allowed classes the top-level object in an archive must conform to, for encoding and decoding.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object which you use when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An object representing the location of a resource that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
The user canceled the operation (for example, by pressing Command-period).
An object representing a universally unique value that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
The name of the value transformer that attempts to unarchive data stored inside a keyed archive in an object you provide.
The name of the value transformer that attempts to unarchive data from an object you provide.
The XPC connection was interrupted.
An interface to the user’s defaults database, where you store key-value pairs persistently across launches of your app.
Waits for any pending asynchronous updates to the defaults database and returns; this method is unnecessary and shouldn't be used.
An abstract class used to transform values from one representation to another.
Returns the class of the value returned by the receiver for a forward transformation.
Registers the observer object to receive KVO notifications for the key path relative to the object receiving this message.
Update your apps to use new features, and test your apps against API changes.
Learn about changes to the macOS SDK.

https://developer.apple.com/library/arch.title: Foundation Release Notes for macOS 10.13 and iOS 11

titleInlineContent.text: Foundation Release Notes for macOS 10.13 and iOS 11

value.text: A universally unique value that can be used to identify types, interfaces, and other items.
A representation of a specific point in time, independent of any calendar or time zone.
A static, plain-text Unicode string object.
A static ordered collection of objects.
A static byte buffer in memory.
An object that represents the location of a resource, such as an item on a remote server or the path to a local file.
A static collection of objects associated with unique keys.
